datastewardship.chapter:
Before you decide to embark on any new study, it is nowadays good practice to consider all options to keep the data generation part of your study as limited as possible. It is not because we can generate massive amounts of data that we always need to do so. Creating data with public money is bringing with it the responsibility to treat those data well and (if potentially useful) make them available for re-use by others. So, given the research question you would like to address, a very first question should always be
Are there any data sets available in the world that are relevant to your planned research?
You know that this is very unlikely? This question is not only about data sets that are similar to what you want to determine yourself, but also reference data or data that should be mined from the existing literature. Further, it is very likely that you will refer to related data, e.g. other databases where you usually "quickly look something up", but that could maybe be properly integrated, especially if you need to do such lookups multiple times.
Will you be referring to any earlier measured data, reference data, or data that should be mined from existing literature? Your own data as well as data from others?
Much of todays data is used in comparison with reference data. A genome for instance is compared with a reference genome to identify genomic variants. If you use reference data, there are several other issues that you should consider.
Do you know where the reference data is available, what the conditions for use are, and how to reference it?
Do you know the data format of the reference data? Is this suitable for your work? Does it need to be converted?
Many reference data sets evolve over time. If the reference data set changes, this may affect your results. If different versions of a reference data set exist, you need to establish your "version policy".
If there are different versions available, you have to decide with all project partners together which version you will be using. Probably you will go for the latest release as of the date of the start of your research project. However, if you have other data from older projects that need to be merged, you may need to consider using the same release you used for a previous project.
If the reference changes while you are working on your research project, you need to decide whether you will follow these changes. Most likely that will mean that you have to do some analyses again, so you will need to make sure enough resources are available to do so. You can decide to stay with the version that you started with; this can have the disadvantage that you will not benefit from added information or added consistency.
Even if you will be producing your own data, you often will also be relying on existing data sets. You may need to integrate your new data with an existing data set or retrieve additional information from related data bases. Will you be doing such things?
Did you research all the data that exists? You may not be aware of all existing data that could be available. Although using and/or integrating existing data sets may pose a challenge, it will normally be cheaper than collecting everything yourself. Even if you decide not to use an existing data set, it is better to do this as a conscious decision!
For all data that is not your own, do you know who owns the data, and how to get access? Obviously, this question and the followup questions will need to be answered for every data set you plan to use.
I guess that means you will not be using the existing data anyway.
Will you enter into a collaboration with the owners of the original data that you plan to use? Will they be available to help you with integration questions? Will they be linking their work to you?
If the data that you will re-use is coupled to people, Is the informed consent that was originally obtained from those people including your current research?
What will you not be allowed to do with the existing data? Will this pose any problems to your project? How are you ensuring that you will adhere to the usage restrictions?
Will you have full access of the data (i.e. will you receive a copy) or will you be have access in another way (i.e. via a web site with restricted questions or by running your own analysis on the computer of the data owners? Will this be seamless for your research?
Data formats can vary, and evolve. For each existing data source you need to ask yourself whether it has the same format as you are using yourself. Differences could also be in the terms used to fill in the data (e.g. are they using "cancer" or "malignant neoplasm"? or maybe a term from a different language?).
If you are combining data from different sources, harmonization may be required. You may need to re-analyse some original data.
If a data source that you are using is being updated over time, this can affect your results. You therefore need to decide what you will do when the data source changes: will you be able to keep using the same old version (documented) for all your analyses? Or will you always be using the latest version at any moment in time? Will you re-do any analysis if the source changes? How can you ensure reproducibility of your own results?
Can you use all the data from the existing source in the form in which it is available? Or will you need to curate the data? Will you be making a subset? Can you make a subset easily? How will you document these efforts so that others can reproduce what you did?
Are you aware of all the existing data that you may be able to use? Are you confident that you know what you could use?
Who will do the work to integrate the existing data sources? Is it known how this needs to be done exactly?
Will you be gathering data from the scientific literature?
Will you be using text mining tools to get the data from the literature? Unless the data you are extracting is in one or a few tables in a few papers, you may need an expert in text mining literature data to be able to get a consistent result with a reasonable effort.
The power of data is unleashed when different sources containing different types of existing data are linked together. Will you be doing that?
Unless the coupling is of a type that has been done numerous times before in similar ways, this kind of job can be tricky. It may be a good idea to have someone knowledgeable in this field check whether you need to take any special provisions.
If a data source that you are using is being updated over time, this can affect your results. You therefore need to decide what you will do when the data source changes: will you be able to keep using the same old version (documented) for all your analyses? Or will you always be using the latest version at any moment in time? Will you re-do any analysis if the source changes? How can you ensure reproducibility of your own results?
How will it affect your project if the format in which the original data is available is changed?
Will you need to be performing a format conversion, translate items, or do you need to change the data you couple to to another nomenclature? In that case, make sure you plan enough time for this.
Will your coupling of existing data be a new data set that contains the relations between the two original data sets, and link back to the sources? Or will you ingest the data that you will be coupling and combine it into a single new source? This decision has implications for data ownership, data access, and for the burden of maintenance.
Will you be creating data that others will use as reference data later?
Will you be doing biobanking?
